**Neil Patrick Harris** (born June 15, 1973)[1] is an American actor, writer,
producer, comedian, magician, and singer. He is known primarily for his comedy
roles on television and his dramatic and musical stage roles. On television,
he is known for playing the title character on _[Doogie Howser,
M.D.](/wiki/Doogie_Howser,_M.D. "Doogie Howser, M.D.")_ (1989–1993), [Barney
Stinson](/wiki/Barney_Stinson "Barney Stinson") on _[How I Met Your
Mother](/wiki/How_I_Met_Your_Mother "How I Met Your Mother")_ (2005–2014, for
which he was nominated for four [Emmy Awards](/wiki/Emmy_Awards "Emmy
Awards")), and [Count Olaf](/wiki/Count_Olaf "Count Olaf") on _[A Series of
Unfortunate Events](/wiki/A_Series_of_Unfortunate_Events_\(TV_series\) "A
Series of Unfortunate Events \(TV series\)")_ (2017–).

Harris is also known for his role as the title character in [Joss
Whedon](/wiki/Joss_Whedon "Joss Whedon")'s musical _[Dr. Horrible's Sing-Along
Blog](/wiki/Dr._Horrible%27s_Sing-Along_Blog "Dr. Horrible's Sing-Along
Blog")_ (2008) and a fictional version of himself in the _[Harold&
Kumar](/wiki/Harold_%26_Kumar "Harold & Kumar")_ film series (2004–2011). His
other films include _[Starship Troopers](/wiki/Starship_Troopers_\(film\)
"Starship Troopers \(film\)")_ (1997), _[Beastly](/wiki/Beastly_\(film\)
"Beastly \(film\)")_ (2011), _[The Smurfs](/wiki/The_Smurfs_\(film\) "The
Smurfs \(film\)")_ (2011), _[The Smurfs 2](/wiki/The_Smurfs_2 "The Smurfs 2")_
(2013), _[A Million Ways to Die in the
West](/wiki/A_Million_Ways_to_Die_in_the_West "A Million Ways to Die in the
West")_ (2014), and _[Gone Girl](/wiki/Gone_Girl_\(film\) "Gone Girl
\(film\)")_ (2014). In 2014, he starred in the title role in _[Hedwig and the
Angry Inch](/wiki/Hedwig_and_the_Angry_Inch_\(musical\) "Hedwig and the Angry
Inch \(musical\)")_ on [Broadway](/wiki/Broadway_theatre "Broadway theatre"),
for which he won the 2014 [Tony Award for Best Leading Actor in a
Musical](/wiki/Tony_Award_for_Best_Leading_Actor_in_a_Musical "Tony Award for
Best Leading Actor in a Musical").

Harris has hosted the [Tony Awards](/wiki/Tony_Awards "Tony Awards") in 2009,
2011, 2012, and 2013, for which he won several special class Emmy Awards.[2]
He also hosted the [Primetime Emmy Awards](/wiki/Primetime_Emmy_Awards
"Primetime Emmy Awards") in 2009 and 2013, and hosted the [87th Academy
Awards](/wiki/87th_Academy_Awards "87th Academy Awards") in 2015, thus making
him the first openly gay man to host the [Academy Awards](/wiki/Academy_Awards
"Academy Awards").[3]

Harris was named one of _[Time](/wiki/Time_\(magazine\) "Time \(magazine\)")_
magazine's 100 Most Influential People in 2010.[4] He is married to [David
Burtka](/wiki/David_Burtka "David Burtka"). In 2010, they had twins using
surrogacy.

## Early life

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Neil_Patrick_Harris_with_Emily_Expo.jpg/220px-
Neil_Patrick_Harris_with_Emily_Expo.jpg)](/wiki/File:Neil_Patrick_Harris_with_Emily_Expo.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Neil_Patrick_Harris_with_Emily_Expo.jpg "Enlarge")

Neil Patrick Harris interviewed by Emily Expo at the Calgary Expo 2015

Harris was born in [Albuquerque, New Mexico](/wiki/Albuquerque,_New_Mexico
"Albuquerque, New Mexico")[1] and grew up [Ruidoso, New
Mexico](/wiki/Ruidoso,_New_Mexico "Ruidoso, New Mexico"), with his elder
brother and their parents, Sheila Gail (née Scott; born 1946) and Ronald Gene
Harris (born 1946). His parents were lawyers and also ran a
restaurant.[5][6][7][8][9] He attended [La Cueva High
School](/wiki/La_Cueva_High_School "La Cueva High School") in Albuquerque,
graduating with high honors in 1991.[10]

## Career

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Neil_Patrick_Harris_by_Gage_Skidmore.jpg/220px-
Neil_Patrick_Harris_by_Gage_Skidmore.jpg)](/wiki/File:Neil_Patrick_Harris_by_Gage_Skidmore.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Neil_Patrick_Harris_by_Gage_Skidmore.jpg "Enlarge")

Harris at the 2008 [Comic Con](/wiki/Comic-Con_International "Comic-Con
International") in [San Diego](/wiki/San_Diego "San Diego"),
[California](/wiki/California "California")

### Film

Harris began his career as a [child actor](/wiki/Child_actor "Child actor")
and was discovered by playwright [Mark Medoff](/wiki/Mark_Medoff "Mark
Medoff") at a drama camp in [Las Cruces, New
Mexico](/wiki/Las_Cruces,_New_Mexico "Las Cruces, New Mexico").[11] Medoff
later cast him in the 1988 drama film _[Clara's Heart](/wiki/Clara%27s_Heart
"Clara's Heart")_, starring [Whoopi Goldberg](/wiki/Whoopi_Goldberg "Whoopi
Goldberg") and based on the novel of the same name by [Joseph
Olshan](/wiki/Joseph_Olshan "Joseph Olshan"). _Clara 's Heart_ earned Harris a
[Golden Globe](/wiki/Golden_Globe_Awards "Golden Globe Awards") nomination.
The same year, he starred in _[Purple People
Eater](/wiki/Purple_People_Eater_\(film\) "Purple People Eater \(film\)")_ , a
children's fantasy.

Harris' first film role as an adult was 1995's _[Animal
Room](/wiki/Animal_Room "Animal Room")_ , although he portrayed a teenager.
His subsequent film work has included supporting roles in _[The Next Best
Thing](/wiki/The_Next_Best_Thing "The Next Best Thing")_ , _[Undercover
Brother](/wiki/Undercover_Brother "Undercover Brother")_ , and _[Starship
Troopers](/wiki/Starship_Troopers_\(film\) "Starship Troopers \(film\)")_.
Harris plays a fictionalized, hyper-womanising, lewd version of himself, in
many ways a polar-opposite to his actual self, in the _Harold and Kumar_
[stoner](/wiki/Stoner_film "Stoner film") [comedy films](/wiki/Comedy_film
"Comedy film") _[Harold& Kumar Go to White
Castle](/wiki/Harold_%26_Kumar_Go_to_White_Castle "Harold & Kumar Go to White
Castle")_, _[Harold& Kumar Escape from Guantanamo
Bay](/wiki/Harold_%26_Kumar_Escape_from_Guantanamo_Bay "Harold & Kumar Escape
from Guantanamo Bay"),_ and _[A Very Harold& Kumar 3D
Christmas](/wiki/A_Very_Harold_%26_Kumar_3D_Christmas "A Very Harold & Kumar
3D Christmas")_.

In 2010, Harris provided [voice acting](/wiki/Voice_acting "Voice acting") for
the role of the adult [Dick Grayson](/wiki/Dick_Grayson "Dick Grayson")
([Nightwing](/wiki/Nightwing "Nightwing")) in the animated film _[Batman:
Under the Red Hood](/wiki/Batman:_Under_the_Red_Hood "Batman: Under the Red
Hood")_ and the [beagle](/wiki/Beagle "Beagle") Lou in the film _[Cats& Dogs:
The Revenge of Kitty Galore](/wiki/Cats_%26_Dogs:_The_Revenge_of_Kitty_Galore
"Cats & Dogs: The Revenge of Kitty Galore")_. The same year, he played the
lead in the [indie](/wiki/Independent_film "Independent film") comedy _[The
Best and the Brightest](/wiki/The_Best_and_the_Brightest_\(film\) "The Best
and the Brightest \(film\)")_.[12] On March 7, 2010, he made a surprise
appearance at the [82nd Academy Awards](/wiki/82nd_Academy_Awards "82nd
Academy Awards"), delivering the opening musical number. He starred in the
films _[The Smurfs](/wiki/The_Smurfs_\(film\) "The Smurfs \(film\)")_ (2011)
and _[The Smurfs 2](/wiki/The_Smurfs_2 "The Smurfs 2")_ (2013).

In 2014, Harris showed a more serious side in _[Gone
Girl](/wiki/Gone_Girl_\(film\) "Gone Girl \(film\)")_ , directed by [David
Fincher](/wiki/David_Fincher "David Fincher"). Harris co-starred in the film
as Desi Collings, the wealthy and obsessed ex-boyfriend of Amy Dunne, played
by [Rosamund Pike](/wiki/Rosamund_Pike "Rosamund Pike"). Harris has said: "I
was pinching myself at the opportunity" to work with Fincher, he received
general praise from critics for his performance, as did the film.[13]

On February 22, 2015, Harris hosted the [87th Academy
Awards](/wiki/87th_Academy_Awards "87th Academy Awards"); it was his first
time hosting the ceremony, and the first time an openly gay man hosted the
[Academy Awards](/wiki/Academy_Awards "Academy Awards").[3][14]

### Stage

Harris has worked on Broadway in both musical and dramatic roles. He played
[Tobias Ragg](/wiki/Tobias_Ragg "Tobias Ragg") in the 2001 concert
performances of _[Sweeney Todd](/wiki/Sweeney_Todd_\(musical\) "Sweeney Todd
\(musical\)")_. In 2002, he performed beside [Anne Heche](/wiki/Anne_Heche
"Anne Heche") in _[Proof](/wiki/Proof_\(play\) "Proof \(play\)")_. In 2003, he
took the role of the Emcee in _[Cabaret](/wiki/Cabaret_\(musical\) "Cabaret
\(musical\)")_ alongside [Deborah Gibson](/wiki/Debbie_Gibson "Debbie Gibson")
and [Tom Bosley](/wiki/Tom_Bosley "Tom Bosley"). As a result of his critically
acclaimed performance in _Cabaret_ , Harris was named the top-drawing
headliner in the role of the Emcee by GuestStarCasting.com, outranking fellow
celebrity stars [John Stamos](/wiki/John_Stamos "John Stamos") and [Alan
Cumming](/wiki/Alan_Cumming "Alan Cumming").[15] In 2004, he performed the
dual role of the Balladeer and [Lee Harvey Oswald](/wiki/Lee_Harvey_Oswald
"Lee Harvey Oswald") on Broadway in the musical revival of [Stephen
Sondheim](/wiki/Stephen_Sondheim "Stephen Sondheim")'s
_[Assassins](/wiki/Assassins_\(musical\) "Assassins \(musical\)")_. He also
sang the role of Charles (first played by [Anthony
Perkins](/wiki/Anthony_Perkins "Anthony Perkins")) on the
[Nonesuch](/wiki/Nonesuch_Records "Nonesuch Records") recording of Sondheim's
_[Evening Primrose](/wiki/Evening_Primrose_\(musical\) "Evening Primrose
\(musical\)")_ and portrayed [Mark
Cohen](/wiki/Rent_\(musical\)#Main_characters "Rent \(musical\)") in the 1997
touring company of the musical _[Rent](/wiki/Rent_\(musical\) "Rent
\(musical\)")_ , a role he satirized on the January 10, 2009, episode of
_[Saturday Night Live](/wiki/Saturday_Night_Live "Saturday Night Live")_ ,
which he hosted.

In 2010, Harris directed a production of the [rock musical](/wiki/Rock_musical
"Rock musical") _[Rent](/wiki/Rent_\(musical\) "Rent \(musical\)")_ at the
[Hollywood Bowl](/wiki/Hollywood_Bowl "Hollywood Bowl"); he cast his
_[Beastly](/wiki/Beastly_\(film\) "Beastly \(film\)")_ co-star [Vanessa
Hudgens](/wiki/Vanessa_Hudgens "Vanessa Hudgens") as Mimi.[16] In 2011, Harris
played the lead role of Bobby in [Stephen Sondheim](/wiki/Stephen_Sondheim
"Stephen Sondheim")'s _[Company](/wiki/Company_\(musical\) "Company
\(musical\)")_ with the [New York Philharmonic](/wiki/New_York_Philharmonic
"New York Philharmonic") in concert, opposite [Patti
LuPone](/wiki/Patti_LuPone "Patti LuPone") and others.[17] The same year, he
directed _The Expert at the Card Table_ at Broad Stage's Edye in [Santa
Monica, California](/wiki/Santa_Monica,_California "Santa Monica,
California").[18]

Harris has hosted the Tony Awards four times: the [63rd Tony
Awards](/wiki/63rd_Tony_Awards "63rd Tony Awards") on June 7, 2009,[19] [65th
Tony Awards](/wiki/65th_Tony_Awards "65th Tony Awards") on June 12, 2011, the
[66th Tony Awards](/wiki/66th_Tony_Awards "66th Tony Awards") on June 10,
2012, and the [67th Tony Awards](/wiki/67th_Tony_Awards "67th Tony Awards") on
June 9, 2013. Only Dame [Angela Lansbury](/wiki/Angela_Lansbury "Angela
Lansbury"), with five ceremonies, has hosted the Tony Awards more times.[20]
Hosting the Tony Awards has earned him three [Emmy Awards](/wiki/Emmy_Awards
"Emmy Awards"); in 2010, 2012, and 2013 for the 63rd, 65th, and 66th
respectively.[21]

A week after hosting the Tonys, it was announced that Harris would portray the
titular role in the first Broadway production of the rock musical _[Hedwig and
the Angry Inch](/wiki/Hedwig_and_the_Angry_Inch_\(musical\) "Hedwig and the
Angry Inch \(musical\)")_ , which he did from March through August
2014.[22][23] Harris went on to win the 2014 [Tony Award for Best Actor in a
Musical](/wiki/Tony_Award_for_Best_Actor_in_a_Musical "Tony Award for Best
Actor in a Musical").[24]

### Television

Beginning in 1989, Harris played the title role of a child prodigy doctor in
_[Doogie Howser, M.D.](/wiki/Doogie_Howser,_M.D. "Doogie Howser, M.D.")_ , for
which he was nominated for a [Golden Globe](/wiki/Golden_Globe_Awards "Golden
Globe Awards"). After the show's four-season run ended in 1993, Harris played
a number of [guest roles](/wiki/Guest_role "Guest role") on television series,
including _[Murder She Wrote](/wiki/Murder_She_Wrote "Murder She Wrote")_.
From 1999 to 2000, he starred with [Tony Shalhoub](/wiki/Tony_Shalhoub "Tony
Shalhoub") in the [NBC](/wiki/NBC "NBC") sitcom _[Stark Raving
Mad](/wiki/Stark_Raving_Mad_\(TV_series\) "Stark Raving Mad \(TV series\)")_ ,
which lasted 22 episodes. He has played lead roles in a number of made-for-
television features including _[Snowbound: The Jim and Jennifer Stolpa
Story](/wiki/Snowbound:_The_Jim_and_Jennifer_Stolpa_Story "Snowbound: The Jim
and Jennifer Stolpa Story")_ in 1994, _[My Ántonia](/wiki/My_Antonia_\(film\)
"My Antonia \(film\)")_ in 1995, _The Christmas Wish_ in 1998, _[Joan of
Arc](/wiki/Joan_of_Arc_\(miniseries\) "Joan of Arc \(miniseries\)")_ in 1999,
_The Wedding Dress_ in 2001, and _The Christmas Blessing_ in 2005.

From 2005 to 2014, Harris played [Barney Stinson](/wiki/Barney_Stinson "Barney
Stinson"), a serial womanizer, in the [CBS](/wiki/CBS "CBS") ensemble sitcom
_[How I Met Your Mother](/wiki/How_I_Met_Your_Mother "How I Met Your
Mother")_. The role earned him
[Emmy](/wiki/Primetime_Emmy_Award_for_Outstanding_Supporting_Actor_in_a_Comedy_Series
"Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Comedy Series")
nominations every year from 2007 to 2010.

In 2008, Harris guest-starred on _[Sesame Street](/wiki/Sesame_Street "Sesame
Street")_ as the Sesame Street Fairy Shoe Person.[25][26][27] In 2009, he
hosted the 7th Annual [TV Land Awards](/wiki/TV_Land_Awards "TV Land Awards")
and appeared as a guest judge on Season 9 of _[American
Idol](/wiki/American_Idol_\(season_9\) "American Idol \(season 9\)")_.[28]

Harris hosted the [61st Primetime Emmy
Awards](/wiki/61st_Primetime_Emmy_Awards "61st Primetime Emmy Awards") on
September 20, 2009. On August 21, 2010, he won two [Emmy
Awards](/wiki/Emmy_Award "Emmy Award") at the Creative Arts Emmy Awards
ceremony, one of which was for his guest performance in the television series
_[Glee](/wiki/Glee_\(TV_series\) "Glee \(TV series\)")_.[29] Harris hosted the
[65th Primetime Emmy Awards](/wiki/65th_Primetime_Emmy_Awards "65th Primetime
Emmy Awards") on September 22, 2013, marking his second time hosting the
event.[21][30][31]

After a preview at the San Diego Comic-Con, a musical episode of _[Batman: The
Brave and the Bold](/wiki/Batman:_The_Brave_and_the_Bold "Batman: The Brave
and the Bold")_ featuring Harris as the villainous [Music
Meister](/wiki/Mayhem_of_the_Music_Meister! "Mayhem of the Music Meister!")
premiered on October 23, 2009, on [Cartoon Network](/wiki/Cartoon_Network
"Cartoon Network"). As a character who could make anyone do his bidding by
singing, he spent most of the episode singing several original songs.[32]

In 2010, Harris filmed a [pilot](/wiki/Television_pilot "Television pilot")
episode for an American adaptation of the British [game show](/wiki/Game_show
"Game show") _[The Cube](/wiki/The_Cube_\(game_show\) "The Cube \(game
show\)")_ as host, though it was not picked up to series.[33]

In 2014, Harris turned down the chance to replace [David
Letterman](/wiki/David_Letterman "David Letterman") as host of the [_Late
Show_](/wiki/Late_Show_\(CBS_TV_series\) "Late Show \(CBS TV series\)") on
[CBS](/wiki/CBS "CBS"), stating that he feared he would get bored of the
repetition that hosting a nightly talk show would entail. He also rejected the
suggestion of replacing [Craig Ferguson](/wiki/Craig_Ferguson "Craig
Ferguson") as host of [_The Late Late
Show_](/wiki/The_Late_Late_Show_\(CBS_TV_series\) "The Late Late Show \(CBS TV
series\)") on the same grounds.[34]

On September 15, 2015, _[Best Time Ever with Neil Patrick
Harris](/wiki/Best_Time_Ever_with_Neil_Patrick_Harris "Best Time Ever with
Neil Patrick Harris")_ , a live [variety series](/wiki/Variety_show "Variety
show") hosted by Harris on [NBC](/wiki/NBC "NBC"), made its debut but was
cancelled after an eight-episode run.[35]

On January 15, 2016, [Netflix](/wiki/Netflix "Netflix") cast Harris in the
television adaptation of _[A Series of Unfortunate
Events](/wiki/A_Series_of_Unfortunate_Events_\(TV_series\) "A Series of
Unfortunate Events \(TV series\)")_ , in which he stars as [Count
Olaf](/wiki/Count_Olaf "Count Olaf"), the main antagonist.[36]

On March 31, 2017, NBC picked up Harris' game show titled _[Genius
Junior](/wiki/Genius_Junior "Genius Junior")_ , the format will test the
smarts of the most brilliant children in the country. Harris will serve as
host and executive producer. The series received a 10-episode order and will
debut sometime in the 2017–2018 season.[37]

### Magic

Harris is a fan of [magic](/wiki/Magic_\(illusion\) "Magic \(illusion\)"),
like his character on _How I Met Your Mother_. His character in _[American
Horror Story: Freak Show](/wiki/American_Horror_Story:_Freak_Show "American
Horror Story: Freak Show")_ was also a magician. Harris'
_[Glee](/wiki/Glee_\(TV_series\) "Glee \(TV series\)")_ character performed
magic as well. He previously served as the President of the Board of Directors
of Hollywood's [Magic Castle](/wiki/The_Magic_Castle "The Magic Castle").[38]
Harris won the [Tannen's Magic Louis Award](/wiki/Tannen%27s_Magic_Shop
"Tannen's Magic Shop") in 2006 and hosted the 2008 World Magic Awards on
October 11, 2008. Additionally, Harris and partner David Burtka were guests of
honor for a _[Top Chef Masters](/wiki/Top_Chef_Masters#Episode_4:_Magic_Chefs
"Top Chef Masters")_ episode which took place at the Magic Castle.

### Other media

In 2007, Harris worked with [Mike Nelson](/wiki/Michael_J._Nelson "Michael J.
Nelson") on an audio commentary for [RiffTrax](/wiki/RiffTrax "RiffTrax"). The
two "riffed" on the film _[Willy Wonka& the Chocolate
Factory](/wiki/Willy_Wonka_%26_the_Chocolate_Factory "Willy Wonka & the
Chocolate Factory")_. Harris is a big fan of the cult TV series Nelson worked
on, _[Mystery Science Theater 3000](/wiki/Mystery_Science_Theater_3000
"Mystery Science Theater 3000")_. Harris was interviewed for a 1992 [Comedy
Central](/wiki/Comedy_Central "Comedy Central") special _This Is MST3K_ hosted
by [Penn Jillette](/wiki/Penn_Jillette "Penn Jillette") about the series and
its fans.[39] In 2008, Harris played the title role in [Joss
Whedon](/wiki/Joss_Whedon "Joss Whedon")'s musical web series _[Dr. Horrible's
Sing-Along Blog](/wiki/Dr._Horrible%27s_Sing-Along_Blog "Dr. Horrible's Sing-
Along Blog")_ alongside [Nathan Fillion](/wiki/Nathan_Fillion "Nathan
Fillion") and [Felicia Day](/wiki/Felicia_Day "Felicia Day"). The first
episode of the series debuted on July 15, 2008.[40] He has also provided his
voice for the [Disney California Adventure
Park](/wiki/Disney_California_Adventure_Park "Disney California Adventure
Park") attraction [California Screamin'](/wiki/California_Screamin%27
"California Screamin'").[41]

On December 11, 2010, Harris hosted the [Spike Video Game
Awards](/wiki/Spike_Video_Game_Awards "Spike Video Game Awards").[42]

In October 2014, Harris released a [memoir](/wiki/Memoir "Memoir") titled
_Neil Patrick Harris: Choose Your Own Autobiography_ , which is structured
like a [Choose Your Own Adventure](/wiki/Choose_Your_Own_Adventure "Choose
Your Own Adventure") book. His [autobiography](/wiki/Autobiography
"Autobiography") spent two weeks on [_The New York Times_ Best Seller
List](/wiki/The_New_York_Times_Best_Seller_list "The New York Times Best
Seller list").[43] His debut [young adult](/wiki/Young_adult_fiction "Young
adult fiction") novel, _The Magic Misfits_ , was released in November 2017 and
is the first in a four-book series of the same name.[44][45][46]

## Personal life

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/DavidBurtkaNeilPatrickHarrisHWOFSept2011.jpg/220px-
DavidBurtkaNeilPatrickHarrisHWOFSept2011.jpg)](/wiki/File:DavidBurtkaNeilPatrickHarrisHWOFSept2011.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:DavidBurtkaNeilPatrickHarrisHWOFSept2011.jpg "Enlarge")

Harris with his husband [David Burtka](/wiki/David_Burtka "David Burtka") at
his ceremony to receive a star on the [Hollywood Walk of
Fame](/wiki/Hollywood_Walk_of_Fame "Hollywood Walk of Fame") on September 15,
2011

Harris confirmed that he is [gay](/wiki/Gay "Gay") on November 4, 2006, by
saying, "I am happy to dispel any rumors or misconceptions and am quite proud
to say that I am a very content gay man living my life to the fullest and feel
most fortunate to be working with wonderful people in the business I
love."[47]

Harris attended the Emmy Awards in September 2007 with his fiancé [David
Burtka](/wiki/David_Burtka "David Burtka"), later confirming the relationship.
In an interview on _[The Ellen DeGeneres Show](/wiki/The_Ellen_DeGeneres_Show
"The Ellen DeGeneres Show")_ ,[48] Harris said his relationship with Burtka
began in 2004. On August 14, 2010, Harris announced that he and Burtka were
expecting twins via a [surrogate mother](/wiki/Surrogate_mother "Surrogate
mother").[49][50] Their son, Gideon Scott, and daughter, Harper Grace, were
born in October 2010.[51][52]

Following the passage of the [Marriage Equality
Act](/wiki/Marriage_Equality_Act_\(New_York\) "Marriage Equality Act \(New
York\)") in New York on June 24, 2011, Harris and Burtka announced their
[engagement](/wiki/Engagement "Engagement") via Twitter,[53] stating that they
had proposed to each other five years earlier but kept the engagement secret
until [same-sex marriage](/wiki/Same-sex_marriage "Same-sex marriage") became
legal.[54] On September 8, 2014, Harris announced on his Twitter page that
[David Burtka](/wiki/David_Burtka "David Burtka") and he were married over the
weekend in [Italy](/wiki/Italy "Italy").[55][56][57][58] [Pamela
Fryman](/wiki/Pamela_Fryman "Pamela Fryman"), the long-time director of _How I
Met Your Mother_ , officiated the wedding while [Elton John](/wiki/Elton_John
"Elton John") performed at the reception.[59][60][61]

Harris lives in New York City in the [Upper Manhattan](/wiki/Upper_Manhattan
"Upper Manhattan") neighborhood of [Harlem](/wiki/Harlem "Harlem").[62]

## Philanthropy

Alongside his acting career, Harris has supported and contributed to various
charities, organization, and foundations. These include:[63]

Foundation[64] and in September 2016, he and his husband were the honorary
